critique: This document primarily deals with the reorganization of the Civil Service Commission and labor-management relations within the federal service. It establishes the Office of Personnel Management, the Merit Systems Protection Board, and the Federal Labor Relations Authority. It also amends several executive orders related to federal personnel management and labor relations. There is no mention of immigration, so it is neutral. The document appears to strengthen the federal government's role in managing its workforce and labor relations, suggesting a slight increase in federal control. There is no discussion of national security or civil liberties. The document seems to favor government intervention in labor management, so it is slightly interventionist. There is no discussion of social inclusion. The document does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt.
